Ambassadors Celebrate
Lebanese Independence
by A. Al-Shabkhoun
On Tuesday November 25, the
anniversary of Lebanese Independence, Yousseff Siyyah,
press attache of the Lebanese Embassy, and Clovis Maksoud, ambassador of the League of Arab
States, spoke to an ample crowd
on the state of Lebanon in the
Clipper Room at 6:00 p.m.
The evenings events started
with the symbolic planting of a
cedar at Hopkins. The cedar,
which is depicted on the Lebanese
flag, was mentioned by Siyyah,
who stated, "Today we offer with
pride and love a symbol that the
Bible talks about. We offer the
Immortal Cedar of Lebanon."
Siyyah's speech was riddled
with despair, while maintaining a
hopeful tone.
"The Lebanese," stated
Siyyah, "still insist on celebrating
their independence day, despite
all the heartache and pain.
Lebanon has had more invading
armies than any other country in

the world.
"To live in Lebanon," asserted
Siyyah, "is to live with violence
while resisting the horrors of a
war that is not ours but is fought
on our soil."
According to Siyyah, a great
asset to the Lebanese people is
that "each Lebanese is fiercely
devoted to life. The Lebanese
decided long ago to keep their
country from dying."
Siyyay also stressed the importance of Lebanon. "No city in the
Middle East is like Lebanon.
Lebanon will always be a necesity," noting that Lebanon has been
a "liason between the Arab and
outside world" and that it is the
"cultural nerve center" of the
Middle East.
Siyyah also pleaded for the
departure of unwanted foreign
troops from Lebanon. "To give
a chance for Lebanon to resolve
its domestic disputes, the immediate withdrawal of all unwanted foreign armies is
imperative."

Remebering the loss of
American lives in Lebanon,
Siyyah reflected, "Lebanon remains in gratitude to the U.S. for
the sacrifices that it has made. We
felt the U.S. deaths in Lebanon
as our own, and will continue to
foster strong relations with this
great country."
Ending his speech, Siyyah
stated, "We have paid the high
price of war. There is no need for
us to pay for peace," before adding a final plea, "Give us peace,
and we shall once more astound
the whole world."
Maksoud next took the podium
and opened by stating, "A symbolic gesture made today comes
on the eve of a new era. Perhaps
a new era in U.S.-Lebanese relations will start with the announcement that shoddy deals were
made by Israel with Iran."
Maksoud hoped that this would
"open the hearts and minds of the
American people in response to

India's South Africa Policy
Clarified by Diplomat Rham
by Weijen Chang
South Africa was the subject of
Monday,
on
discussion
November 24, as A.N. Rham,
the Deputy Chief of Indian Mission in Washington, D.C., came
to Homewood to speak about India's present foreign policy
toward South Africa, both the
present pro-apartheid Botha administration and the African National Congress. Sponsored by
the Indian Students Association
and co-sponsored by the International Studies Fund and
Chaplain's Office of Johns
Hopkins, the lecture was held in
the Multi-Purpose Room in AMR
I at 8:00 pm.
Introduced by Deepti Kharod,
the president of the Indian
Students Association, Rham
began by giving what he called "a
historical perspective of what is
behind the rationale of Indian
policy toward South Africa."
Rham maintained that South
Africa was "the laboratory for
the 'Indian experiment,— that is,
the philosophy of using nonviolent means for achieving
political ends, "[which] was
evolved, conceived, born, and
perfected in South Africa."
He continued by relating some
of Gandhi's experiences in South
Africa, and how they shaped later
Indian foreign policy. Rham
described the social situation in
South Africa in Gandhi's time,

saving, "If one was white, one
was infallible.. . .If one was
black, one was inferior," later
adding that ". . present-day
South Africa is similar."
Gandhi's fight against inequality in India, Rham said, grew to
encompass the inequalities of all
subjugated peoples, including
those of Southeastern Asia and,
most importantly, South Africa.
"Our freedom [that of the Indian
people was therefore indivisible
from that of peoples around the
world,- commented Rham.
Rham brought up India's precedent of protesting ,partheid in
South Africa as evidence of its
solidarity with the subjugated
South African people.
Rham's introduction of India's
"non-aligned" philosophy of
solidarity with "freedom fighters
around the world," including
those in South Africa, led into his
thoughts on the present-day social
and political situation in South
Africa, and India's continued
policy of protest toward the Botha
administration. Repeatedly bringing up the injustices of apartheid
South Africa, Rham related India's present policy toward South
Africa, that is the policy of no
political or economic relations
with the Botha administration. He
urged that the countries of the
world "bring upon South Africa
all the pressure they can possibly
bear."
After the lecture, Rham field-

ed numerous questions from the
audience. These included questions about possible Indian
military aid to the African National Congress, the current
reluctancy of Great Britain to
bring sufficient pressure upon
South Africa, and Indian aid to
the "frontline states," those
countries bordering South Africa.
Questions from the audience were
so numerous that Rham was
unable to answer them all in the
allotted time, and continued the
question-answer session after the
lecture to those interested.
Rham himself is currenily
Deputy Chief of the Indian
Ministry in Washington, D.C.,
and has served in the Indian
Foreign Service since 1962.
Rham received a Master's Degree
in Economics from the Delhi
School of Economics, and has
since served in the Indian Missions -in Paris, Khartoum, New
York, Bangkok, and Tokyo, and
has served as Indian High Commissioner to Zambia and
Botswana.
Deepti Kharod, president of the
Indian Students Association, later
said that the ISA hopes to sponsor similar lectures this upcoming semester, including one about
international economics and one
about Indian culture. Also slated
for next semester is a workshop
with an Indian classical dancer
and other events.

SC Announces Chairmen
For Next Year's Spring Fair
by Kathleen McCarthy
During the Student Council
meeting last Wednesday, COC
Committee Chair and SC VicePresident Simran Brara announced the selection of seniors Don
Chang and Mel Coursey as
Spring Fair 1987 Co-Chairs.
Brara further reported that no
selection had yet been made for
the position of Spring Fair
Treasurer. In fact, Brara reopened the position and is currently
accepting applications.
Associate Dean of Students
Chris Colombo also appeared to
speak to the Student Council.
Colombo addressed the formulation of a task force to evaluate the
University Orientation program.
Such a task force has been formed, under the auspices of the Office of the Dean of Students, to
evaluate the program—to ascertain its goals and objectives, to incorporate suggestions, apply
criticisms; and to implement
modifications or expansions.
The task force, expected to
submit a formal evaluation in
Feburary 1987, consists of both
administrative and student
representatives. The members include: Susan Boswell of the Dean
of Students office, senior Ken
Hansen, Orientation '86 Advising
Co-Chair; senior Mary Hiatt,
Orientation '86 Chair; senior

Mark Komisky, Student Council
President; Tracey Lyon, Assistant Director of Residential Life;
Andrea Perry, Director of
Residential Life; and Mary Ellen
Porter, Director of Student Activities. Colombo asked that any
students who feel that they could
contribute something to the
evaluation please speak to the
Committee.
Colombo welcomed the
possibility of such potential input
and solicited people with different
perspectives on any angle of the
program. The Associate Dean did
advise that much of the work
would be done during the Intersession period, because of the
time impetus.
Colombo generally spoke approvingly of the program, coin-

paring it favorably with those of
other, similar institutions. He
stressed the integral parts both the
administration and the students
play in the successful operation of
Orientation. Colombo further
claimed that Orientation itself
plays a significant role in making
the first year at Hopkins an enjoyable one for the student. The
Student Council seemed to be in
concordance with the Dean's
remarks.
Other news:
*Junior Class President Sahir
Surmeli announced the advent of
a night at Prs for the Junior
Class. The date is planned for
Monday, December 8, from 8-11
pm. Pizza and beverages will be
available.

Sudler Art Prize Nominations Accepted by Leys
by A. Al-Shabkhoun

Fite Photo

Ruth Leys, who is coordinating the committee to determine a senior to
win the $1,000 Sudler Art Prize.

"I wish to encourage students
to apply for the [Sudler] Prize,"
commented Ruth Leys, assistant
Dean for Program Development
and this year's coordinator of the
committee to recommend a winner to University President
Steven Muller, who will make the
final choice.
The Sudler Prize in the Arts is
annually awarded at fourteen
universities including Harvard,
the
Yale,
Princeton,
Massachusettes Institute of
Technology and Hopkins.
The $1000 prize is awarded at
commencement and is open for
submission for all graduating
seniors from Homewood and all
fourth-year students from the
School of Medicine.
According to a memorandum
distributed by Muller, the prize is
awarded based on "excellence or
the highest proficiency in the performance , execution, or composition in one of the following

general areas: music, theater,
painting, sculpture, or visual
media such as film, photography
or videotape." Leys also added
that in addition, "we would
welcome poetry, fiction, theater,
or other writing submissions."
Leys noted that the prize was
awarded to a playwright in 1984.
Leys also stressed that although
the prize is meant to draw the
"very best talent" it is "aimed at
the general student" and not
necessarily the aspiring artist.
The selection process for the
prize includes submitting a sample of work, supporting
documents such as reviews, a
resume, and nomination.
Nominations may either be made
by a faculty of the University or
students
may
nominate
themselves as long as they include
a letter of recommendation from
a University faculty member or
administrator who is familiar with
the student's work. All nominations are due by March 31.
According to Leys, the submis-

sion of a sample work can include
"two to four pieces of visual art,
a manuscript, a videotape, or an
audio tape" depending on the
medium.
The committee composed of
faculty and administrators from
various divisions of Hopkins then
assesses the work and makes a
recommendation to Muller.
Inquiries about the prize and
submissions should be directed to
Leys in Merryman Hall 143
(x8215).
The Sudler Prize was initiated
in 1983 and "is made possible
through the generosity of Mr.
Louis Sudler, chairman of Sudler
and Company, Chicago," commented Muller in his memorandum on the prize.
According to Leys, "Sudler's
main interest is music. He was
Chairman of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He wants to encourage students to make a conribution to art, and believes that
arts have a strong contribution to
make to education."

Internship. To land a decent
one. The mission.
Last summer I stayed in
Baltimore. I worked at a decent
internship. I began each day with
a ride on the Hopkins shuttle. The
best excursion was when a group
of children filed aboard with their
chaperons, something about a
visit to an industrial museum. The
boys called the girls, "things"
and the girl who protested did so
by poking a boy in the ribs and
refusing to say the word "thing,"
instead referring to "that word."
Ignoring the feminine threat, one
boy accused another of turning
into a "thing," to which the second replied, "No, don't worry.
This is a thing-protector." He
tapped his digital watch.
At work I learned two lessons.
Never use more than one size of
paper. The smaller sheets will get
lost. Always be polite in conversation. Never know when you
have to call again.
Living in Baltimore in the summer I learned one lesson. Don't
do it again.
Looking at the internship
possibilities for this year, some of
which include "three to four page
autobiography and several personal references" or which find
1000 applicants for 10 positions,
I wonder if! have been caught in
the vortex of "careerism." That
vaguely dirty word refers to a
new trend among college
students, the intense preparation
for a career and the neglect of
"liberal" education. A Carnegie
Foundation report released last
month found nine out of ten high
school students and parents saw
college as a place to prepare for
a job. This is no surprise.
The confrontation between
those who think themselves practical and those who think
themselves scholarly is a little like
the scene on the bus. The former
are the boys, proud of gadgets
and impervious in a smug credo
of successs. The latter are like the
girls, most of whom took the
abuse, or like the lone critic,
unable to confront the actual
issue.
Sometimes the careerists will
taunt the others about "real
work." But in a society where the
most money is made by acting,
playing baseball or shuffling
merger papers, who is to say
what this mythical real work is?

In return, the once-proud
academy boasts of "culture." To
a generation long past being lost
and now happily remembering
"Happy Days" in place of reality, this too is just an empty brag.
The problem is a defect of our
culture. Although higher education should not shrink from any
challenge, neither should it be expected to alter single-handedly the
values of society by impressing
upon every passerby for four
years the importance of "higher
education." If change is to come,
it cannot come by a decree of core
curriculum or with a composition
requirement. That sort of thing
breeds contempt and a dishonest
interest.
There is an attitude problem involved all around. In the
dogmatic attack, people suppose
that what is good for one is good
for many. Whether it is the goal
of becoming a doctor or a lawyer,
there is something to be said for
dreams and for the single-minded
pursuit.
Furthermore, there is no real
schism, only the legacy of
Descartes, Marx, and wellintentioned parents. If the practical and the ideal are mutually
exclusive, it is only because they
are believed to be. Without that
realization, only makeshift solutions will be manufactured.
Education. To find it. The
means?

As a very concerned member of
the Hopkins community, I'm sure
that I was not the only one to find
reading last week's editorial
pages a draining experience; and
as a member of the Coalition, I
found it even more so. Since the
start of this year, the Coalition
has come under such massive attack from the community that we
repeatedly find ourselves spending an unprecedented amount of
time and energy defending
everything from our goals to our
organization to our tactics. Again
and again we are accused of the
same things in editorial letters:
that the majority of blacks in S.
Africa do not approve of sanctions, that Divestment by foreign
investors will only hurt the
blacks, that our tactics are
counter-productive
and/or
alienating, that Divestment can do
no good in S. Africa but will in-

stead damage this University, and
of course, that it's none of our
business what this University
does with its money.
I took it as an indication that
these criticisms needed no further
repetition when last week I inserted a clean piece of paper in
my typewriter before I even read
the editorial letters. After reading
them, I am reassured that I was
not over-reacting. Furthermore,
despite my vow that I would not
perpetuate this cycle and defend
the Coalition once again, I am
still tempted to do so. I restrain
myself because I am aware that
the Coalition has more than adequately defended itself against all
of these charges more than once.
I write this letter only to ask if our
opponents have been paying any
attention whatsoever to our
responses. Being continually
forced to justify the same actions
leads me to believe that we are
fighting a losing battle against individuals who are in no way
serious about resolving the issues
they raise, but who have instead
closed their minds to any information that might conflict
with their own and are now resorting to mere harassment.
This same attitude is evident in
those who profess to champion
our goals but condemn our tactics. The Coalition welcomes
anyone who feels they have found
a way to further the antiApartheid cause and to help
blacks in S. Africa achieve the
rights and privileges they
deserve, to do so. The tactical
question should not be at the
forefront of this movement. Not
only are we open to all suggestions made within our group and
to members of our own group, we
would fully endorse any antiApartheid movement separate
from our own on this campus.
Ultimately, we realize as many of
our opponents do not seem to,
that the end is the most important
aspect of any move for change
and that the means should be only secondary.
It seems that at this stage most
arguments for and against divestment, and for and against the
Coalition, have been fully explored in these editorial pages.
Further attacks along the same
lines only compel the Coalition to
again defend itself and indicate
that someone is deliberately not
listening. It is apparent now that
the editorial shouting match of
this semester is growing increasingly futile. Action is the only
way that the S. African racist
regime will fall and that the
senseless suffering there will end.
I urge anyone who feels in deep
disagreement with the Coalition
on a tactical basis alone to take
this to heart and initiate any action that they believe will do more
good for S. African blacks than
ours has.
Sondra Guttman

As sunset falls over the
Charles Village area, the ivory
tower world of Hopkins slams its

nasty things to happen upon them.

the Hopkins Security Office was
to travel in packs, if one is compelled to wander through the
streets which lie to the east of the
campus. Yet, a pack of young
men, who had taken the security
office advice, were accosted by a
villain with a revolver in the wee
hours of the morning. Safety in
numbers does not exist between
the hours of 1 am-6 am. According to Major Robert
Larkin, head of Hopkins Security, an unaccompanied female
should not go out into the night.

Studies of the Eye and Its Diseases the Focus
of Johns kil Hopkins' Wilmer Eye Institute
by Uri Ahn

Retinitis pigmentosa is an eye
disease that causes the lightsensitive photoreceptive cells on
the retina to degenerate and eventually become useless. Other eye
diseases hinder the ability of the
photoreceptor cells to absorb
light, or kills the cells, causing
blindness. Dr. Ruben Adler,
associate professor of ophthalmology and neurosciences, and his
team of colleagues at the Wilmer
Eye Institute of the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine are in
the process of studying and "attempting to understand these
light-sensitive photoreceptor
cells, whose mysteries hide the
cures for many eye diseases.
To study these cells, Dr. Adler
has devised a method that has
greatly increased our chances of
understanding the photoreceptor
cells. He first carefully dissects
an 8-day old chick embryo to
remove the retina. He then treats
this undeveloped tissue with enzymes to loosen them up, thus
creating a suspension of isolated
single cells. These cells are then
treated with two groups of
chemicals: one that keeps them
alive, and another that settles the
cells, causing them to individually stick to the bottom of a dish.
The fact that these cells are
isolated allows Dr. Adler to pick
out individual cells to observe and
study. This sometimes involves
the use of a video camera that
captures the growth and development of the cell on videotape for
others to observe. From studying
the growth of individual photoreceptor cells, Dr. Adler is trying to find out what these cells
need in order to stay alive and
function, the pathological agents

that
normal genes can cause their
degeneration.
To understand the factors that
keep the photoreceptor cells alive
and functioning, different conditions must be considered. First,
Dr. Adler observes the effects
different substances that might
come into contact with these cells
have on the individual cells.
Then, knowing that within the
retina photoreceptor cells are in
contact with many other different
types of cells (neurons, glial) he
tries to identify the contributions
that these various cells have on
the well-being of the photoreceptor cells. The goal of the study is
to identify the nutrients necessary
for keeping the photoreceptor
cells healthy.
Finding pathological agents
that kill these cells involves the
same method of experimentation
in finding which chemicals or
substances cause harm to the
cells. Finding the health-deterring
agents will then increase the
chances of finding a way to effectively protect the cell.
It is well-known that the
presence of certain abnormal
genes causes the cells to
degenerate. To understand exactly what cell deficiencies and inabilities an abnormal gene
creates, Adler is trying to find the
special environment that allows
the cells to function properly
despite their inabilities. Actual
experimentation and study of ths
problem involves the photoreceptor cells of newborn mice—
normal mice and a strain of mice
that have the defective gene.
Adler then compares the reactions
of these two different types of
cells to ultimately find the proper
environment that the defective
cells need in order to survive.

improve today's therapies by
making them shorter and less
traumatic for the kids and thus
letting them get on with their
lives.
Each physician carries on
research in addition to his or her
treatment of patients. Dr. Corder
is currently exploring the effects
that Cisplatin, a soluble derivative
of the element platinum, has on
solid tumors. This drug has been
successful in the treatment of
germ cell tumors, but in some
cases has side effects that can
cause kidney and hearing problems. Corder has been trying to
minimize the toxicity of the drug
while maintaining its effectiveness.
Platinum has also been found to
be effective in the treatment of
brain tumors, which account for
one third of all tumors in
children. Because brain tumors in
children are often inoperable, and
, the brain is highly sensitive to

radiation treatments, a new approach has been sought after.
Corder, along with Leventhal and
Strauss have been working with
drugs that are combinations
which include platinum. Platinum
is an element that can cross the
brain-blood barrier that exists and
drugs made with it have been effective in shrinking pediatric
brain tumors and thus postponing
possible radiation or surgery.
Dr. Graham is currently studying how certain drugs effect
leukemia in children. One in particular is Methtrexate, which has
been proven to be an integral part
of a patient's therapy. Today,
with drugs like this one, they expect to cure the "average" patient where 10 or 12 years ago
they could not have. But still
these doctors are not satisfied.
They want to make the treatment
shorter, create a pill form of the
drug to take away needless shots,
and IV's, and simply make it as
easy as possible on the kids, some
of whom are too young to even

understand what is happening.
Although 901of leukemia partients can be cured, the possibility of remission remains. One
treatment then used is a bone
marrow transplant. Dr. Civin,
along with Dr. Strauss. is studying ways to make this treatment
more effective in leukemia pa.
tients. They are observing the
growth processes of the stem cells
in the marrow and how cancer
causing genes called oncogenes,
give rise to tumors. They are also
working on ways to reduce the
possibility of rejection by the
transplant of the body. In a
transplant immune cells can be
moved along with the stem cells,
but now an antibody has been
developed to separate the
necessary stem cells and
transplant them only.
The team method employed
down at the center does not include just these 5 doctors. There
are radiologists. neurosurgeons,
social workes, child life workers,
psychiatrists, and others who are

a part of it. Cancer in children
causes incredible problems emotionally as well as financially in
both the patient and the family.
These people realize that their patients are still developing, as well
as emotionally,and have special
problems. Through financial
assistance from the Children's
Cancer Foundation cheery, pleasant playrooms, ward, and parent
rooms have been added to ease
some of the pain. A new "state
of the art" out-patient center is
also being planned.
Although kids can be "tough as
heck." special care and attention
are necessary in the treatment of
cancer in children. These five
doctors and the Hopkins
Children's Center are doing all
that they can do to make an impossible situation a little easier on
the patients as well as for the
parents.

J.V. Hoopsters Rocked In Home Opener
by Patrick Furey
The JV basketball team opened its season with two losses, one
at Cecil Community College and
the other at home to Mary
Washington. Though the defeats
were quite decisive, the team has
been improving gradually under
first-year coach Web Johnson.
In the opener, the Blue Jays
were overwhelmed by the
quickness of Cecil Community.
Hopkins fell behind early because
of costly turnovers, and Cecil
never looked back. Freshmen
Dave Seklir provided almost all
of the JV's offense in the first
half, as he scored twelve points
and did a good job on the boards.
The second half was no easier for
the Jays, as Cecil continued to
fast-break and hustle past
Hopkins defenders. Dave Kramer
did an excellent job at point
guard, and along with Noah
Rosenberg ("the best 5'8" power
forward in the game" according
to Coach Johnson), provided
some excitement in the closing
minutes.
Last Tuesday's game against
Mary Washington saw a great improvement in the Blue Jays.

Guard Steve Blumenthal led the
Hopkins attack with some unpressive outside shooting and
some solid ball handling. The
Blue Tide's press was handled extremely well by the Jays, and for
a while in the second half, it looked as if Hopkins was going to
make the game extremely close.
Once again, however, poor rebounding .put the game out of
reach. If it weren't for Seklirs
eleven rebounds, MWC would
have dominated completely.
Eventually, the Blue Tide pulled
away for a 75-39 victory.
Only one thing can be said after
being drubbed in the first two
games—the only way to go is up.
Right now, injuries are hurting
the JV, with Rosenberg (toe) and
Eric Pifer (shoulder) sidelined for
a few weeks. The return of Scott
FitzGerald to the lineup,
however, should give the Blue
Jays a much needed spark.
Hopkins plays three games this
week—Saturday at Penn State
(York), Tuesday at Howard
Community College, and
Wednesday at home against Penn
State (Ogontz). Hopefully, they
will continue to improve.

by A. Al-Shabkhoun
On Tuesday November 25, the
anniversary of Lebanese Independence, Yousseff Siyyah,
press attache of the Lebanese Embassy, and Clovis Maksoud, ambassador of the League of Arab
States, spoke to an ample crowd
on the state of Lebanon in the
Clipper Room at 6:00 p.m.
The evenings events started
with the symbolic planting of a
cedar at Hopkins. The cedar,
which is depicted on the Lebanese
flag, was mentioned by Siyyah,
who stated, "Today we offer with
pride and love a symbol that the
Bible talks about. We offer the
Immortal Cedar of Lebanon."
Siyyah's speech was riddled
with despair, while maintaining a
hopeful tone.
"The Lebanese," stated
Siyyah, "still insist on celebrating
their independence day, despite
all the heartache and pain.
Lebanon has had more invading
armies than any other country in

the world.
"To live in Lebanon," asserted
Siyyah, "is to live with violence
while resisting the horrors of a
war that is not ours but is fought
on our soil."
According to Siyyah, a great
asset to the Lebanese people is
that "each Lebanese is fiercely
devoted to life. The Lebanese
decided long ago to keep their
country from dying."

Middle East is like Lebanon.
Lebanon will always be a necesity," noting that Lebanon has been
a "liason between the Arab and
outside world" and that it is the
"cultural nerve center" of the
Middle East.

departure of unwanted foreign
troops from Lebanon. "To give
a chance for Lebanon to resolve
its domestic disputes, the immediate withdrawal of all unwanted foreign armies is
imperative."

Remebering the loss of
American lives in Lebanon,
Siyyah reflected, "Lebanon remains in gratitude to the U.S. for
the sacrifices that it has made. We
felt the U.S. deaths in Lebanon

foster strong relations with this
great country."

us to pay for peace," before adding a final plea, "Give us peace,

the whole world."

"open the hearts and minds of the
American people in response to

India's South Africa Policy
Clarified by Diplomat Rham
by Weijen Chang
South Africa was the subject of
Monday,
on
discussion
November 24, as A.N. Rham,
the Deputy Chief of Indian Mission in Washington, D.C., came
to Homewood to speak about India's present foreign policy
toward South Africa, both the
present pro-apartheid Botha administration and the African National Congress. Sponsored by
the Indian Students Association
and co-sponsored by the International Studies Fund and
Chaplain's Office of Johns
Hopkins, the lecture was held in
the Multi-Purpose Room in AMR
I at 8:00 pm.
Introduced by Deepti Kharod,
the president of the Indian
Students Association, Rham
began by giving what he called "a
historical perspective of what is
behind the rationale of Indian
policy toward South Africa."
Rham maintained that South
Africa was "the laboratory for
the 'Indian experiment,— that is,
the philosophy of using nonviolent means for achieving
political ends, "[which] was
evolved, conceived, born, and
perfected in South Africa."
He continued by relating some
of Gandhi's experiences in South
Africa, and how they shaped later
Indian foreign policy. Rham
described the social situation in
South Africa in Gandhi's time,

saving, "If one was white, one
was infallible.. . .If one was
black, one was inferior," later
adding that ". . present-day
South Africa is similar."
Gandhi's fight against inequality in India, Rham said, grew to
encompass the inequalities of all
subjugated peoples, including
those of Southeastern Asia and,
most importantly, South Africa.
"Our freedom [that of the Indian
people was therefore indivisible
from that of peoples around the
world,- commented Rham.
Rham brought up India's precedent of protesting ,partheid in
South Africa as evidence of its
solidarity with the subjugated
South African people.
Rham's introduction of India's
"non-aligned" philosophy of
solidarity with "freedom fighters
around the world," including
those in South Africa, led into his
thoughts on the present-day social
and political situation in South
Africa, and India's continued
policy of protest toward the Botha
administration. Repeatedly bringing up the injustices of apartheid
South Africa, Rham related India's present policy toward South
Africa, that is the policy of no
political or economic relations
with the Botha administration. He
urged that the countries of the
world "bring upon South Africa
all the pressure they can possibly
bear."
After the lecture, Rham field-

ed numerous questions from the
audience. These included questions about possible Indian
military aid to the African National Congress, the current
reluctancy of Great Britain to
bring sufficient pressure upon
South Africa, and Indian aid to
the "frontline states," those
countries bordering South Africa.
Questions from the audience were
so numerous that Rham was
unable to answer them all in the
allotted time, and continued the
question-answer session after the
lecture to those interested.
Rham himself is currenily
Deputy Chief of the Indian
Ministry in Washington, D.C.,
and has served in the Indian
Foreign Service since 1962.
Rham received a Master's Degree
in Economics from the Delhi
School of Economics, and has
since served in the Indian Missions -in Paris, Khartoum, New
York, Bangkok, and Tokyo, and
has served as Indian High Commissioner to Zambia and
Botswana.
Deepti Kharod, president of the
Indian Students Association, later
said that the ISA hopes to sponsor similar lectures this upcoming semester, including one about
international economics and one
about Indian culture. Also slated
for next semester is a workshop
with an Indian classical dancer
and other events.

The $1000 prize is awarded at
commencement and is open for

School of Medicine.

distributed by Muller, the prize is
awarded based on "excellence or
the highest proficiency in the performance , execution, or composition in one of the following

general areas: music, theater,
painting, sculpture, or visual
media such as film, photography
or videotape." Leys also added
that in addition, "we would
welcome poetry, fiction, theater,
or other writing submissions."
Leys noted that the prize was
awarded to a playwright in 1984.
Leys also stressed that although
the prize is meant to draw the
"very best talent" it is "aimed at
the general student" and not
necessarily the aspiring artist.
The selection process for the
prize includes submitting a sample of work, supporting
documents such as reviews, a
resume, and nomination.
Nominations may either be made
by a faculty of the University or
students
may
nominate
themselves as long as they include
a letter of recommendation from
a University faculty member or
administrator who is familiar with
the student's work. All nominations are due by March 31.

sion of a sample work can include
"two to four pieces of visual art,
a manuscript, a videotape, or an
audio tape" depending on the
medium.
The committee composed of
faculty and administrators from
various divisions of Hopkins then
assesses the work and makes a
recommendation to Muller.

Internship. To land a decent
one. The mission.
Last summer I stayed in
Baltimore. I worked at a decent
internship. I began each day with
a ride on the Hopkins shuttle. The
best excursion was when a group
of children filed aboard with their
chaperons, something about a
visit to an industrial museum. The
boys called the girls, "things"
and the girl who protested did so
by poking a boy in the ribs and
refusing to say the word "thing,"
instead referring to "that word."
Ignoring the feminine threat, one
boy accused another of turning
into a "thing," to which the second replied, "No, don't worry.
This is a thing-protector." He
tapped his digital watch.
At work I learned two lessons.
Never use more than one size of
paper. The smaller sheets will get
lost. Always be polite in conversation. Never know when you
have to call again.
Living in Baltimore in the summer I learned one lesson. Don't
do it again.
Looking at the internship
possibilities for this year, some of
which include "three to four page
autobiography and several personal references" or which find
1000 applicants for 10 positions,
I wonder if! have been caught in
the vortex of "careerism." That
vaguely dirty word refers to a
new trend among college
students, the intense preparation
for a career and the neglect of
"liberal" education. A Carnegie
Foundation report released last
month found nine out of ten high
school students and parents saw
college as a place to prepare for
a job. This is no surprise.
The confrontation between
those who think themselves practical and those who think
themselves scholarly is a little like
the scene on the bus. The former
are the boys, proud of gadgets
and impervious in a smug credo
of successs. The latter are like the
girls, most of whom took the
abuse, or like the lone critic,
unable to confront the actual
issue.
Sometimes the careerists will
taunt the others about "real
work." But in a society where the
most money is made by acting,
playing baseball or shuffling
merger papers, who is to say
what this mythical real work is?

In return, the once-proud
academy boasts of "culture." To
a generation long past being lost
and now happily remembering
"Happy Days" in place of reality, this too is just an empty brag.
The problem is a defect of our
culture. Although higher education should not shrink from any
challenge, neither should it be expected to alter single-handedly the
values of society by impressing
upon every passerby for four
years the importance of "higher
education." If change is to come,
it cannot come by a decree of core
curriculum or with a composition
requirement. That sort of thing
breeds contempt and a dishonest
interest.
There is an attitude problem involved all around. In the
dogmatic attack, people suppose
that what is good for one is good
for many. Whether it is the goal
of becoming a doctor or a lawyer,
there is something to be said for
dreams and for the single-minded
pursuit.
Furthermore, there is no real
schism, only the legacy of
Descartes, Marx, and wellintentioned parents. If the practical and the ideal are mutually
exclusive, it is only because they
are believed to be. Without that
realization, only makeshift solutions will be manufactured.
Education. To find it. The
means?

As a very concerned member of
the Hopkins community, I'm sure
that I was not the only one to find
reading last week's editorial
pages a draining experience; and
as a member of the Coalition, I
found it even more so. Since the
start of this year, the Coalition
has come under such massive attack from the community that we
repeatedly find ourselves spending an unprecedented amount of
time and energy defending
everything from our goals to our
organization to our tactics. Again
and again we are accused of the
same things in editorial letters:
that the majority of blacks in S.
Africa do not approve of sanctions, that Divestment by foreign
investors will only hurt the
blacks, that our tactics are
counter-productive
and/or
alienating, that Divestment can do
no good in S. Africa but will in-

stead damage this University, and
of course, that it's none of our
business what this University
does with its money.
I took it as an indication that
these criticisms needed no further
repetition when last week I inserted a clean piece of paper in
my typewriter before I even read
the editorial letters. After reading
them, I am reassured that I was
not over-reacting. Furthermore,
despite my vow that I would not
perpetuate this cycle and defend
the Coalition once again, I am
still tempted to do so. I restrain
myself because I am aware that
the Coalition has more than adequately defended itself against all
of these charges more than once.
I write this letter only to ask if our
opponents have been paying any
attention whatsoever to our
responses. Being continually
forced to justify the same actions
leads me to believe that we are
fighting a losing battle against individuals who are in no way
serious about resolving the issues
they raise, but who have instead
closed their minds to any information that might conflict
with their own and are now resorting to mere harassment.
This same attitude is evident in
those who profess to champion
our goals but condemn our tactics. The Coalition welcomes
anyone who feels they have found
a way to further the antiApartheid cause and to help
blacks in S. Africa achieve the
rights and privileges they
deserve, to do so. The tactical
question should not be at the
forefront of this movement. Not
only are we open to all suggestions made within our group and
to members of our own group, we
would fully endorse any antiApartheid movement separate
from our own on this campus.
Ultimately, we realize as many of
our opponents do not seem to,
that the end is the most important
aspect of any move for change
and that the means should be only secondary.
It seems that at this stage most
arguments for and against divestment, and for and against the
Coalition, have been fully explored in these editorial pages.
Further attacks along the same
lines only compel the Coalition to
again defend itself and indicate
that someone is deliberately not
listening. It is apparent now that
the editorial shouting match of
this semester is growing increasingly futile. Action is the only
way that the S. African racist
regime will fall and that the
senseless suffering there will end.
I urge anyone who feels in deep
disagreement with the Coalition
on a tactical basis alone to take
this to heart and initiate any action that they believe will do more
good for S. African blacks than
ours has.
Sondra Guttman

'My Favorite Records' A Critic's Picksfor '86
by Sue Trowbridge
Ten-best lists have always
seemed like such a presumptuous
concept. "Best" is a very loaded word, after all; plenty of people will undoubtedly look at the
list below, and exclaim, "Hey! I
though Boston's Third Stage (or
Springsteen's Live, or the Top
Gun soundtrack) was the best
album of the year.Therefore, I'll declare my subjectivity up front, and call the
following list "My Ten Favorite
Records of 1986."
All in all, it's been a pretty
good year for music. The Top 40
was full of the usual dross, with
a few notable exceptions, but look
on the bright sidecWham! broke
up, Peter Gabriel had his first
megahit, and Motley Crue didn't
release a new album.
And there were enough appealing LPs released to ensure plenty of runners-up for this list, including Depeche Mode's Black
Celebration, Anna Domino's
self-titled album, Stutter by
James, and Robyn Hitchcock's
Element of Light. But let's get
right to the ten that were my tops
in pops.
1. The Woodentops, Giant(Columbia). This young British band
doesn't need to fake exuberance,
sincerity and energy; they've got
them in spades. That's what
makes listening to Giant such a
joyful experience. From the
lightning-fast licks of "Love
Train" to the gentle groove of
"Good Thing," Giant is one
hugely entertaining record.
2. The Woodentops, Well Well
We// (Upside). This compilation

7. The Housemartins, London 0
Hull 4(Elektra). These tour Brits
arc endearing musical Marxists,
setting socially-aware lyrics to the
catchiest of pop tunes. Songs like
Happy Hour" and "Sheep" are
nonstop, upbeat fun, while the
more reflective "Think For A
Minute- and the gospel-tinged
"I'll Be Your Shelter" show the
band's more sober side.
8. The Pretenders, Get Close
(Sire). Chrissic Hynde has come
a long, long way since the cool
rebel stance of her "Precious"
days—she's now the only original
Pretender, a wife and mother,
and definitely grown-up. Gel
Close is a refreshingly mature
rock album, free of gimmicks and
frills, full of solid songwriting
and energetic playing.

E M•
of the 'Tops' early singles doesn't
have Giant's slick and polished
sound. It's closer in spirit to their
fast-and-furious live shows. And
there's more variety among the
songs here—"Steady Steady" is
a masterpiece of cathartic angst,
"Do It Anyway- is a modern
rockabilly romp, and the title
track flirts with but never falls into complete musical anarchy.
3. Throwing Muses, Throwing
Muses (4AD import). Artful
lyrics, nightmare visions,
challenging rhythms. This
Boston-based band establishes a
powerful presence with their
debut LP, thanks largely to
Kristin Hersh's dynamic vocals.
Unpredictable, irresistible rock.
4. R.E.M., Wes Rich Pageant

(I.R.S.). Hooking up with John
Cougar Mellencamp's producer,
Don Gehman, was a potentially
risky move for R.E.M. Would
Lifes Rich Pageant be another sad
sellout to A.O.R. radio?
Thankfully, no; big guitar solos
and tunes about sex, beer, and
rockin all night are not R.E.M.'s
style. Michael Stipe's thoughtful
lyrics are actually understandable
and the songs have more hooks,
but those are changes for the
better.
5. Peter Gabriel, So (Geffen).
"Sledgehammer" is pure excitement, bouncy, funky, and 1986's
best single by far. But there's so
much more to So. Kate Bush adds
an angelic vocal to "Don't Give
Up,- one of the year's most stirring musical moments; "In Your

Eyes- draws on African pop for
inspiration, and "Big Time" proves that Pete's still got a good
sense of humor (he did, after all,
dress up like a flower when he
was in Genesis). A triumph.

6. The Fall, Bend Sinister (Beggars Banquet import). Manchester's fabulous Fall is perhaps
the most consistently good band
in the U.K. Every year they
release a new record, and every
year it's a gem. Mark E. and Brix
Smith lead the Fall through ten
tracks, covering grunge-guitar
garage rock ("Mr. Pharmacist"),
uncharacteristically perky pop
("Shoulder Pads"), and much
more. Mark E.'s curious style of
sing-speak may take sonic getting
used to, but it's worth the effort.

9. That Petrol Emotion, Manic
Pop Thrill (Demon import).
Former members of the seminal
Irish band The Undertones, That
Petrol Emotion's debut LP is indeed a pop thrill. They rock out
gloriously on "Good Thing," but
the band's equally adept at
something as delicate and
beautiful as "A Natural Kind of
Joy." Sure to be a band worth
watching in the future.
10. Red Lorry Yellow Lorry,
Paint Your Wagon (Red Rhino
import). The Lorries, on the
other hand, have no use for
anything that's remotely mellow.
This is hard, uncompromising
music, full of roaring guitars and
set to a brutal beat, sung by a man
with the grimmest, darkest voice
in rock. Turn it up loud, very
loud.

Sheltered Lives

Set in 1960s rural Connecticut,
Sheltered Lives is the poignant

story of a confused young man in
the wake of adolescence. Having
returned home after one year of
service in Vietnam, David Winant finds himself displaced. Old
relationships no longer have the
comfortable familiarity they once
had.
Milburn is slow in setting thc

England town and is plagued with
the inevitable question, "So what

the pace and get on with the plot.
It appears that family members

Science
Studies of the Eye and Its Diseases the Focus
of Johns kil Hopkins' Wilmer Eye Institute
by Uri Ahn

Retinitis pigmentosa is an eye
disease that causes the lightsensitive photoreceptive cells on
the retina to degenerate and eventually become useless. Other eye
diseases hinder the ability of the
photoreceptor cells to absorb
light, or kills the cells, causing
blindness. Dr. Ruben Adler,
associate professor of ophthalmology and neurosciences, and his
team of colleagues at the Wilmer
Eye Institute of the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine are in
the process of studying and "attempting to understand these
light-sensitive photoreceptor
cells, whose mysteries hide the
cures for many eye diseases.
To study these cells, Dr. Adler
has devised a method that has
greatly increased our chances of
understanding the photoreceptor
cells. He first carefully dissects
an 8-day old chick embryo to
remove the retina. He then treats
this undeveloped tissue with enzymes to loosen them up, thus
creating a suspension of isolated
single cells. These cells are then
treated with two groups of
chemicals: one that keeps them
alive, and another that settles the
cells, causing them to individually stick to the bottom of a dish.
The fact that these cells are
isolated allows Dr. Adler to pick
out individual cells to observe and
study. This sometimes involves
the use of a video camera that
captures the growth and development of the cell on videotape for
others to observe. From studying
the growth of individual photoreceptor cells, Dr. Adler is trying to find out what these cells
need in order to stay alive and
function, the pathological agents

that
normal genes can cause their
degeneration.
To understand the factors that
keep the photoreceptor cells alive
and functioning, different conditions must be considered. First,
Dr. Adler observes the effects
different substances that might
come into contact with these cells
have on the individual cells.
Then, knowing that within the
retina photoreceptor cells are in
contact with many other different
types of cells (neurons, glial) he
tries to identify the contributions
that these various cells have on
the well-being of the photoreceptor cells. The goal of the study is
to identify the nutrients necessary
for keeping the photoreceptor
cells healthy.
Finding pathological agents
that kill these cells involves the
same method of experimentation
in finding which chemicals or
substances cause harm to the
cells. Finding the health-deterring
agents will then increase the
chances of finding a way to effectively protect the cell.
It is well-known that the
presence of certain abnormal
genes causes the cells to
degenerate. To understand exactly what cell deficiencies and inabilities an abnormal gene
creates, Adler is trying to find the
special environment that allows
the cells to function properly
despite their inabilities. Actual
experimentation and study of ths
problem involves the photoreceptor cells of newborn mice—
normal mice and a strain of mice
that have the defective gene.
Adler then compares the reactions
of these two different types of
cells to ultimately find the proper
environment that the defective
cells need in order to survive.

The Johns Hopkins Children's Center:
Physician-Scientists for the Little Ones
by Ely Brown
At the Johns Hopkins
Children's Center it is a team effort in the fight against cancer.
Curt Civin, M.D.. Brian Corder,
M.D., Ph.D., Michael Graham,
M.D.,, Brigid Leventhal, M.D.,
and Lewis Strauss, M.D. are five
physician-scientists who have
dedicated their lives to the study
and treatment of pediatric
oncology.
These doctors are part of the
new breed of medical practitioners who are not only involved in the treatment and diagnosis
of cancer, but are also part of the
research and investigation end of
the spectrum; ergo the name
physician-scientist. Although
conventional means are still used
to treat patients, these doctors are
unhappy with current therapies,
drugs, and treatments because of
the pain, time and money involved with them. Although cancer in
anyone is tragic, it is particularly heartrending and unfair to see

it strike a child. Because of this
fact, these doctors are trying to
improve today's therapies by
making them shorter and less
traumatic for the kids and thus
letting them get on with their
lives.
Each physician carries on
research in addition to his or her
treatment of patients. Dr. Corder
is currently exploring the effects
that Cisplatin, a soluble derivative
of the element platinum, has on
solid tumors. This drug has been
successful in the treatment of
germ cell tumors, but in some
cases has side effects that can
cause kidney and hearing problems. Corder has been trying to
minimize the toxicity of the drug
while maintaining its effectiveness.
Platinum has also been found to
be effective in the treatment of
brain tumors, which account for
one third of all tumors in
children. Because brain tumors in
children are often inoperable, and
, the brain is highly sensitive to

radiation treatments, a new approach has been sought after.
Corder, along with Leventhal and
Strauss have been working with
drugs that are combinations
which include platinum. Platinum
is an element that can cross the
brain-blood barrier that exists and
drugs made with it have been effective in shrinking pediatric
brain tumors and thus postponing
possible radiation or surgery.
Dr. Graham is currently studying how certain drugs effect
leukemia in children. One in particular is Methtrexate, which has
been proven to be an integral part
of a patient's therapy. Today,
with drugs like this one, they expect to cure the "average" patient where 10 or 12 years ago
they could not have. But still
these doctors are not satisfied.
They want to make the treatment
shorter, create a pill form of the
drug to take away needless shots,
and IV's, and simply make it as
easy as possible on the kids, some
of whom are too young to even

understand what is happening.
Although 901of leukemia partients can be cured, the possibility of remission remains. One
treatment then used is a bone
marrow transplant. Dr. Civin,
along with Dr. Strauss. is studying ways to make this treatment
more effective in leukemia pa.
tients. They are observing the
growth processes of the stem cells
in the marrow and how cancer
causing genes called oncogenes,
give rise to tumors. They are also
working on ways to reduce the
possibility of rejection by the
transplant of the body. In a
transplant immune cells can be
moved along with the stem cells,
but now an antibody has been
developed to separate the
necessary stem cells and
transplant them only.
The team method employed
down at the center does not include just these 5 doctors. There
are radiologists. neurosurgeons,
social workes, child life workers,
psychiatrists, and others who are

a part of it. Cancer in children
causes incredible problems emotionally as well as financially in
both the patient and the family.
These people realize that their patients are still developing, as well
as emotionally,and have special
problems. Through financial
assistance from the Children's
Cancer Foundation cheery, pleasant playrooms, ward, and parent
rooms have been added to ease
some of the pain. A new "state
of the art" out-patient center is
also being planned.
Although kids can be "tough as
heck." special care and attention
are necessary in the treatment of
cancer in children. These five
doctors and the Hopkins
Children's Center are doing all
that they can do to make an impossible situation a little easier on
the patients as well as for the
parents.

quickness of Cecil Community.

never looked back. Freshmen
Dave Seklir provided almost all

the Jays, as Cecil continued to
fast-break and hustle past
Hopkins defenders. Dave Kramer
did an excellent job at point
guard, and along with Noah
Rosenberg ("the best 5'8" power
forward in the game" according
to Coach Johnson), provided
some excitement in the closing
minutes.

Mary Washington saw a great improvement in the Blue Jays.

Hopkins attack with some unpressive outside shooting and

Blue Tide's press was handled extremely well by the Jays, and for

have dominated completely.

away for a 75-39 victory.

Jays a much needed spark.

Community College, and
Wednesday at home against Penn
State (Ogontz). Hopefully, they
will continue to improve.
